header.title: Tuba Veneris: The Trumpet of Venus

central_thesis: This grimoire, ostensibly penned by John Dee in 1580, presents a practical system for invoking and compelling six specific 'infernal' spirits operating under the dominion of Venus. It details the precise crafting and consecration of magical tools—including unique sigils, a ceremonial horn, a protective circle, and the grimoire itself—all meticulously aligned with Venusian astrological timings and numerological principles, while the modern edition critically examines the text's historical context and disputed authorship.

structure_content.summary: This foreword introduces the modern edition, detailing the discovery of Richard Brzustowicz's transcription of the original manuscript. It notes the legendary attribution of the work to John Dee as a wedding gift to Edward Kelly in 1582 and confirms the editor's efforts to bring this rare text into print.

structure_content.chapter_title: Preface from the Translator by Michael Putnam
structure_content.summary: The translator outlines the textual tradition of 'Tuba Veneris,' noting three known manuscripts and a 1794 printed edition. He discusses the scholarly debate surrounding John Dee's authorship, presenting arguments both for and against it, ultimately leaning towards a non-Dee attribution while acknowledging the text's classical Latin style and its place within the Agrippan grimoire tradition.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Magic of Tuba Veneris by Philip Legard
structure_content.summary: This extensive analysis positions 'Tuba Veneris' as a unique text in ritual magic, blending Classical learning with Solomonic and Hermetic influences. Legard explores the concept of 'Black Venus,' the pervasive numerology of six, and the text's 'nigromantic' nature, contrasting it with Dee's known magical practices. He details the historical context, pseudepigraphic tendencies in grimoires, and the book's influence on later German Faustian magic, concluding the work is a sophisticated synthesis of magical theories applied practically, likely composed circa 1620 in Germany.

structure_content.chapter_title: English Text: The Trumpet of Venus - Introduction by Dr. John Dee
structure_content.summary: The author introduces the 'Little Book Sacred to the Black Venus' as a guide to invoking six spirits under Venus. He emphasizes precise ritual preparation and the use of specific invocations to compel spirits to human form without danger, asserting the 'good angels' rule over 'evil spirits' and that these daemons retain their Creator-given names and sigils from their angelic past.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter One: In What Manner the Seal or Character of Venus is to be Prepared
structure_content.summary: Instructions are given for crafting the Seal of Venus from new Cyprian copper. It must be a six-angled plate, engraved with a steel instrument during the day and third or tenth hour of night of Venus, under a new moon. The finished seal is then to be fumigated with vervain, myrtle, and musk, and ritually buried near flowing water.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Two: How the Horn of Venus is to be Made
structure_content.summary: Details the preparation of the Trumpet of Venus using a horn from a live bull. The horn must be washed and purified with vitriol (copper sulfate in wine vinegar) and inscribed with specific characters using a steel instrument, all performed during Venusian hours and under a new moon. It is then fumigated, wrapped, and buried alongside the Seal.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Three: How the Circle is to be Made
structure_content.summary: Describes the creation of the magical circle as a 'strong fortress' against daemons. It is to be made from parchment or virgin paper, with three concentric circles (the largest six feet in diameter) inscribed with Divine Names, angels (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael, Uriel), and evangelists (John, Jesus, Luke, Matthew, Mark, Judeorum) using paints, during Venusian times. The completed circle is fumigated and buried.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter Four: The Invocations of the Spirits, the names particular to them, and in what manner their Sigils are to be Made
structure_content.summary: This section introduces the six 'infernal' spirits under Venus's dominion: Mogarip, Amabosar, Alkyzub, Belzazel, Falkaroth, and Mephgazub. For each spirit, its unique sigil is provided alongside its full, 'barbarous' invocation phrase, forming the core magical utterances for summoning.

structure_content.chapter_title: In What Manner the Sigils of the Spirits are to be Made
structure_content.summary: Provides instructions for manufacturing the individual sigils of the six spirits. These are made from green wax mixed with soot, formed into small round chips, and carved with a steel instrument during the day and hour of Venus. After carving, they are fumigated and buried for preservation until required for operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Consecration of the Little Book
structure_content.summary: Outlines the ritual to consecrate the 'Liber Spirituum' (the grimoire itself). This involves writing its contents and title ('A Little Book Sacred to the Black Venus') in red ink using a dove feather and copper-sulfate ink, and inscribing the Character of Venus and optionally an image of the planet. The book is then baptized with vitriolic water, with a specific invocation to Venus and the Angel Anael, followed by fumigation and burial.

structure_content.chapter_title: How the Operation is to be Carried Out
structure_content.summary: This chapter details the practical performance of the evocation. The operator, prepared and courageous, constructs the circle in a solitary place, wears the Seal of Venus, kindles incense, and uses the Trumpet of Venus to announce the summoning. The spirit is called by its assigned name at the beginning and end of a specific invocation that commands it by Adonai, the Seal, Anael, and the Christian Trinity. Methods for compelling obstinate spirits, such as heating the Seal and placing it on the spirit's wax sigil, are described.

Concluding guidelines for the operation, emphasizing silence from companions, proper handling of any treasure obtained (by placing the Seal of Venus on it and transferring to a consecrated container), and a final admonition for the operator to act wisely, calmly, and charitably (giving alms upon success) to ensure favorable outcomes in this life and the next.

key_concepts.definition: The title of the grimoire, referring to the ceremonial horn used to announce the invocation and banishing of spirits associated with the planet Venus. The work is also known as 'Libellus Veneri Nigro Sacer' (The Little Book Sacred to the Black Venus).

An epithet for Venus used in the text, referring to her chthonic and nocturnal aspects, particularly her association with six infernal spirits. This concept draws from Classical paganism, distinct from standard astrological Venusian magic.

The specific daemons (Mogarip, Amabosar, Alkyzub, Belzazel, Falkaroth, Mephgazub) that are invoked by the grimoire. These spirits are said to operate under the dominion of Venus and the Angel Anael, and their sigils incorporate Venusian, Geomantic (e.g., Amissio, Libra), and astrological symbols.

A six-sided copper sigil, intricately inscribed with Venusian and Geomantic characters. It serves as an authority token for the operator and a tool for compelling obstinate spirits, often by heating it and placing it on the spirit's individual wax sigil.

A ceremonial horn, ideally from a live bull, ritually purified with vitriol (copper sulfate) and wine vinegar, then inscribed with specific characters. It is used to announce the beginning of summonings and the conclusion of banishings, symbolizing its role as the 'trumpet' mentioned in the title.

A consecrated protective barrier constructed from parchment or virgin paper, consisting of three concentric circles inscribed with Divine Names (e.g., TETRAGRAMMATON, JEHOVA, ELOHIM, ADONAY), names of angels (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael, Uriel), and evangelists (John, Jesus, Luke, Matthew, Mark). It acts as a fortress for the operator during invocations.

The grimoire itself, a parchment book where the spirits' names and invocations are inscribed. It undergoes a specific consecration ritual, including inscription of Venusian symbols, baptism with vitriolic water, and an invocation to Anael, transforming it into a potent magical instrument.

The term employed by the author to categorize the magic practiced in the text, referring to the conjuration of spirits. The author distinguishes this practice from 'blasphemous pacts' and frames it as a 'true work of magic' that can be performed without spiritual perdition through the aid of divine and celestial agencies like Anael.

The specific angel identified as the 'chief ruler of the sphere of Venus.' Anael's authority is central to the operational magic, being explicitly invoked to subjugate and command the six daemons during the consecration of the 'Liber Spirituum' and the main summoning rite.

A distinctive characteristic of 'Tuba Veneris,' particularly its pervasive use of the number six. This includes the six-sided Seal, six daemons, and a six-foot diameter circle, drawing on Pythagorean principles that associate six with Venus (as a 'commixtion of both sexes').

practical_system.description: The 'Tuba Veneris' outlines a comprehensive system of nigromantic ritual magic centered on evoking six 'infernal' spirits under Venus's dominion. The system requires meticulous preparation of specific magical implements—a six-sided copper Seal of Venus, a bull's horn as the Trumpet of Venus, a multi-banded parchment Magical Circle, and the grimoire itself (the 'Liber Spirituum')—all consecrated according to strict astrological timings (day and hours of Venus, new moon) and numerological principles. The operation involves constructing the circle, wearing the Seal, kindling Venusian incense, announcing the summoning with the Trumpet, and delivering specific 'barbarous' invocations to compel spirits to appear. Coercion of obstinate spirits is achieved by ritually heating the Seal and applying it to their individual wax sigils. Successful operations involve proper spirit dismissal and a mandate for charity.
tools: Sigils of the Six Spirits (green wax chips mixed with soot)
Red or green cloth (for wrapping consecrated items)
Dove feather (for writing the Liber Spirituum)
Fire/coals or burning candle (for heating the Seal)
rituals: Preparation and Consecration of the Seal of Venus: Crafting a six-sided copper plate, inscribing Venusian and Geomantic characters, fumigating with vervain, myrtle, and musk, and ritual burial.
Preparation and Consecration of the Horn of Venus: Obtaining a live bull's horn, purifying it with vitriol and wine vinegar, inscribing characters, fumigating, and ritual burial.

Preparation and Consecration of the Magical Circle: Creating a parchment circle with three concentric bands inscribed with Divine Names, names of angels (Michael, Gabriel, Raphael, Uriel) and evangelists (John, Jesus, Luke, Matthew, Mark), fumigating, and ritual burial.

Preparation and Consecration of the Liber Spirituum (The Little Book): Writing the grimoire with special ink and a dove feather, inscribing the Character and image of Venus, baptizing it with vitriolic water while invoking Venus and the angel Anael, then fumigating and burying it.
Preparation of Individual Spirit Sigils: Forming small chips from green wax mixed with soot, carving each spirit's sigil with a steel instrument, fumigating, and ritual burial.

The Evocation Operation: Constructing the consecrated circle, wearing the Seal of Venus, kindling incense, using the Trumpet of Venus to announce the summoning, and delivering the specific invocation for the chosen spirit, compelling it by Adonai, the Seal, Anael, and the Christian Trinity.
Spirit Coercion: If a summoned spirit is obstinate, heating the Seal of Venus over fire or a candle and placing it on the spirit's individual wax sigil to cause torment and compel obedience.

Spirit Banishing: Announcing the dismissal with the Trumpet of Venus using specific banishing words ('Norcados Fenoram Anosiren...' followed by the spirit's name), concluding with benediction and thanks, after which the operator may safely leave the circle.
Handling of Treasure: If spirits yield treasure, placing the Seal of Venus atop it and then transferring it to a newly blessed and fumigated container.

relevant_quotes.text: Early magical texts are notoriously pseudepigraphical. The authorship of the Tuba Veneris has been ascribed to John Dee, for the author gives his name as Dee in the text itself. There is, however, much room for doubt.

A final consideration is that the type of magic in the 'Tuba' is of a nigromantic variety in as much as it involves forcibly evoking and binding spirits, whereas the magic that Dee was practicing during the 1580's was of a more religious nature, with prayer as its basis and pious supplication

The name VENUS among the Stars was given to me by the Gods Soon an Infernal dweller is present until the TRUMPET sounds Behold the Daemon groans, subdued by the power of the SIGN Well done! You return from the enemy an honored conqueror.

For you should know that the good angels have been placed over the evil spirits by God Thrice-Greatest and Best so that they should rule over them; on account of which when something is commanded by a good Spirit to a bad one, the former orders and calls the latter by means of his own capable invocation, and this perhaps may be in a language not particular to us mortals, or even comprehensible to us.

I consecrate you, O little black book, to Venus Let the Trumpet of Venus be your name Let it be terrible and well known To all the dwellers of the Underworld. O Great Prince of Heaven Anael! I humbly ask that you strengthen this book, And let it be washed in your spring For your eternal honor.

However, the author has obsessively structured his work around the number six: the seal is six-sided, there are six daemons and the circle is six feet in diameter, and so on. The only other magical text contemporary with the work that has a comparable numerological obsession is the Heptarchia Mystica—a magical work undoubtedly by Dee,

critical_analysis.relevance: This book is highly relevant for understanding the syncretic nature of Renaissance ritual magic, demonstrating a unique synthesis of Classical pagan mythology (specifically regarding Venus's chthonic aspects), Hermetic philosophy (via Agrippa's influence on planetary magic and sigil construction), and Solomonic grimoire traditions. Its disputed authorship offers a compelling case study in pseudepigraphy and the historical circulation of occult knowledge, providing insights into how Dee's reputation was utilized by later authors. The detailed operative instructions make it a valuable primary source for studying historical magical practices and their underlying theoretical frameworks.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience includes academic scholars specializing in Western Esotericism, Renaissance studies, and the history of science and magic. Additionally, practitioners of ritual magic, especially those interested in grimoire traditions, planetary magic, or the works attributed to John Dee, will find this text invaluable for its detailed operative system and its place within the broader magical currents.
